summary: Email correspondence between U.S. and French law enforcement regarding coordination on the investigation of Jean-Luc Brunel. The French police request assistance and information, while the U.S. side states their investigation has not revealed evidence of Brunel's crimes in France or against French victims, and cites confidentiality concerns for not sharing additional information.

persons.name: Jean-Luc Brunel
persons.context: French modeling agent and associate of Jeffrey Epstein, under investigation by French police for rape and for providing women and young girls to Epstein.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Central figure in the case; mentioned as the recipient of women and young girls allegedly provided by Jean-Luc Brunel.

connections.description: French police state they are investigating any implication Brunel had in providing women and young girls for Epstein.

events.title: French Police Request for Coordination
events.description: The French Central Unit for Minors Protection sends an email to U.S. officials requesting coordination and information sharing for their investigation into Jean-Luc Brunel.

events.title: U.S. Declines Direct Response
events.description: A U.S. Assistant Attorney forwards the French request to a DOJ attaché in Paris, stating they will not respond directly as the attaché is the appropriate point of contact.

events.title: U.S. Position Communicated
events.description: A U.S. Assistant Attorney informs the DOJ attaché that their investigation has not found evidence of Brunel's crimes in France or against French victims, and cites confidentiality concerns for not sharing more information.

locations: Nanterre, France (101 rue des Trois Fontanot)
keyFacts: French police are actively investigating Jean-Luc Brunel for rape and for providing women and young girls to Jeffrey Epstein.
French authorities state they have collected victim statements against Brunel but are hindered by the statute of limitations for rape charges.
U.S. authorities state their investigation has not revealed evidence of crimes committed by Brunel in France or against French citizens.
U.S. authorities cite confidentiality concerns as a reason for not providing additional information to French counterparts.
The communication reveals a lack of coordination and information sharing between U.S. and French investigative bodies regarding the Brunel case.
